title: Export Controls: Munitions and Dual-Use Items

structured_sections.heading: Munitions and Dual-Use Items Overview
structured_sections.content: Items, information, and software that are subject to U.S. Export Control Laws and used in a university environment are generally categorized on two main lists: the US Munitions List (USML) and the Commerce Control List (CCL).

structured_sections.heading: US Munitions List (USML) - (ITAR)
structured_sections.content: The USML is published by the U.S. Department of State under the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR). It includes defense articles and services. The categories are: I) Firearms, Close Assault Weapons, and Combat Shotguns; II) Materials, Chemicals, Microorganisms, and Toxins; III) Ammunition/Ordnance; IV) Launch Vehicles, Missiles, Rockets, Torpedoes, Bombs, and Mines; V) Explosives, Propellants, and Incendiary Agents; VI) Vessels of War; VII) Tanks and Military Vehicles; VIII) Aircraft and Associated Equipment; IX) Military Training Equipment; X) Protective Personnel Equipment; XI) Military Electronics; XII) Fire Control, Range Finder, and Guidance Equipment; XIII) Auxiliary Military Equipment; XIV) Toxicological Agents; XV) Spacecraft Systems; XVI) Nuclear Weapons Related Items; XVII) Classified Articles and Defense Services; XVIII) Directed Energy Weapons; XX) Submersible Vessels and Oceanographic Equipment.

structured_sections.heading: Commerce Control List (CCL) - (EAR)
structured_sections.content: The CCL is published by the U.S. Department of Commerce under the Export Administration Regulations (EAR). It includes dual-use items that have both commercial and military applications. The categories are: 0) Nuclear Materials, Facilities and Equipment; 1) Materials, Chemicals, Microorganisms, and Toxins; 2) Materials Processing; 3) Electronics Design, Development, and Production; 4) Computers; 5) Telecommunications and Information Security; 6) Sensors and Lasers; 7) Navigation and Avionics; 8) Marine; 9) Aerospace and Propulsion.
